Subject: Architecture--California--20th century|~|Architects $z 20th century

Relation.isPartOf: Richard and Dion Neutra Papers. Department of Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA
Rights.statementLocal: Copyright has not been assigned to the Department of Special Collections, UCLA. All requests for permission to publish or quote from manuscripts must be submitted in writing to the Manuscripts Librarian. Permission for publication is given on behalf of the Dept. of Special Collections as the owner of the physical items and is not intended to include or imply permission of the copyright holder, which must also be obtained. Deposit material is unavailable for research.|~|Photographs by Julius Shulman may not be copied.|~|Drawings cannot be copied except with the prior written permission of Mr. Dion Neutra.
Description.note: Richard Josef Neutra (1892-1970) was born in Vienna. He was the city architect for Luckenwalde, then worked as a draftsman-collaborator with Erich Mendelsohn in Berlin before immigrating to the United States in 1923. He worked with Frank Lloyd Wright (1924) before settling in Los Angeles. His most productive years were during 1930s and 1940s. In the 1960s, Richard J Neutra worked in partnership with his son Dion. The collection consists of correspondence both personal and professional belonging to Richard J Neutra as well as his wife Dione Neutra, travel records and sketches, publications, drawings, blueprints, oversized rolled plans, audio recordings, and photographs.
Title: Richard and Dion Neutra Papers, 1925-1970
Description.abstract: Richard Josef Neutra was born in 1892 in Vienna. He immigrated to the United States in 1923 to work with the architect Frank Lloyd Wright. Neutra's wife Dione Neutra (1901 – 1990) and their eldest son Frank immigrated in 1924. During the fall of 1924, Frank Lloyd Wright invited Richard Neutra to his Taliesin Estate located in Spring Green, WI where Wright resided and worked. Neutra subsequently moved to Los Angeles, CA in 1925. His most productive years were during the 1930s and 1940s. During his last decade, Richard Neutra worked in partnership with his son Dion (1926 – 2019), who worked on numerous projects in the Neutra and Neutra and Alexander offices. Dione Neutra was involved with her husband's career and served as his executive assistant and publicist. Richard Neutra published several books, including Wie baut Amerika? (1927) and Survival Through Design (1954). He died in 1970.

Description.note: Typed note on photo: From the southeast all of the main office building is a one-story wing providing garage space for several cars.  Narrow horizontal windows break the otherwise smooth plywood wall of the wing.  Story-and-a-half glass section (center) lights broad stairway from the lower level office section to residential suites on second floor.  Landscaping is to follow detailed suggestions of the architect.

Relation.isPartOf: Richard and Dion Neutra Papers. Department of Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA
Description.note: View towards the northern façade of the court of the Louvre showing the pavilion Turgot, the pavilion Richelieu, and the pavilion Colbert.  In the right foreground is the pavilion Mollien.  In the center of the court is a garden containing trees and a statue of a man on a horse (possibly Napoleon).  Note the close-coupled columns, carved stone detail piled upon carved stone detail, pediments within pediments, massive pitched and curved roofs and promiscuous statuary on each of the pavilions.|~|Title supplied by archivist.
Title: Louvre

Description.note: Image appears in "Life and Shape" (1962) by Richard Neutra.Caption in book reads: "All around the globe, ceremonies at frontiers; yet separation is a sham.  Ahmedabad"|~|Group of four people wearing traditional clothing in Jaipur, India.  Two bearded men wearing turban's - one sitting at a desk facing forward, one standing facing right - and two other people - one seated, one standing.|~|Inscription by artist reads "Jaipore."  Signed and dated on bottom right.  An unnumbered drawing of a mosque and car ferry is on the verso.
Title: Jaipore, 1955.

Name.creator: Neutra, Richard Joseph, $d 1892-1970
Subject: Drawings
Relation.isPartOf: Richard and Dion Neutra Papers. Department of Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA
Description.note: View of the Jamuna River area in Agra, India.  [The view is possibly from the grounds of the Taj Mahal on the south bank of the river.  In the left foreground the inside face of the riverfront wall (made of red sandstone) runs along a brick pathway leading to a tower in the right foreground.  The tower (possibly octagonally shaped) is topped with a domed chamber.  On the opposite shore another dome-shaped tower rises above vegetation.  This vegetation area is possibly the Mahtah Bagh or Moonlight Garden.]|~|Inscription by artist reads "Jamuna River / Agra."  Signed and dated on bottom left.
Title: Jamuna River, Agra, [1955].

Name.creator: Neutra, Richard Joseph, $d 1892-1970

Description.note: View of a group of eight [musicians] standing on a raised platform in front of several small groups of people standing and sitting on the ground in Chennai, India.  One group member on stage appears to be holding a drum or symbol, while another group member appears to be playing some type of horn instrument.  All group members on the stage are wearing yellow headdress.  A small boat along the ocean is in the background.|~|Inscription by artist reads "Madras."  Signed and dated on bottom left.
Title: Madras (Chenai, India), 1955.
